In small children, low-energy fractures lead to butter clod fractures or epiphyseal fracture-decollement. Plastic deformation of the bones is also one of the forms encountered at this age.

In children, the most common fractures are epiphyseal dislocations, green wood fractures and metaphyseal fractures.

In adolescents, the fractures encountered are type III or IV epiphyseal dislocations, apophyseal fracture-avulsions and complete fractures.

question.title: What are the most common fractures in children?

option_a.title: Epiphyseal dislocations, green wood fractures, and metaphyseal fractures

option_b.title: Type III or IV epiphyseal dislocations, apophyseal fracture-avulsions, and complete fractures

option_c.title: Butter clod fractures or epiphyseal fracture-decollement and plastic deformation of the bones
option_c.description: Forms of fractures in small children

option_d.title: Green wood fractures, metaphyseal fractures, and complete fractures

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the option
